;埃隆·马斯克表示，他与马克·扎克伯格的潜在面对面战斗将在他的电视上直播社交媒体网站 X，以前称为 Twitter。

;

;这两位科技亿万富翁似乎同意在 6 月底进行一场“笼子比赛”对决。扎克伯格实际上接受过综合武术训练，Facebook 母公司 Meta 的首席执行官发布了有关今年早些时候完成他的第一场柔术锦标赛的消息。

;

;“扎克伯格与马斯克的比赛将在 X 上进行直播，”马斯克周日在该平台上发帖写道。 “所有收益都将捐献给退伍军人慈善机构。”

;

;马斯克周日早些时候表示，他正在通过举重进行战斗训练。

;

;“没有时间锻炼，所以我只是带他们去工作。”马斯克写道。

;

;马斯克和扎克伯格是否真的能登上拉斯维加斯的擂台还有待观察——尤其是马斯克经常过早地发布推文谈论行动或没有跟进。但即使他们的笼子比赛协议只是一个笑话，这种玩笑也引起了人们的关注。

;

;这一切都始于拥有 X 的马斯克回应一条有关 Meta 准备发布一个名为 Threads 的新 Twitter 竞争对手的推文。 。他挖苦世界变得“完全受扎克控制，别无选择”，但随后一位 Twitter 用户开玩笑地警告马斯克，扎克伯格正在接受柔术训练。

;

;“如果马斯克写道。

;

;马斯克表示，X 将为老板针对的用户支付“无限”的法律费用

;

;X、Meta 和 Ultimate Fighting Champions 的代表，后者拥有没有立即回复寻求评论的电子邮件。

;

;马斯克推动在 X 上直播视频之际，他的目标是将该平台变成“数字城镇广场”。然而，他在 5 月份广为人知的 Twitter Spaces 启动活动中，佛罗里达州州长罗恩·德桑蒂斯 (Ron DeSantis) 宣布他竞选美国总统，但由于技术故障和近半小时的延迟，马斯克曾表示，问题在于这是服务器“紧张”的结果，因为很多人试图收听纯音频事件。但即使在最高的时候，列出的听众人数也超过了 420,000 人，远低于电视总统公告所吸引的数百万观众。

;在香港东部水域发现的鲸鱼尸体将于周一下葬，但政府透露，其骨架稍后将用于研究目的。

;

;渔农自然护理署周日表示，已与海洋公园和城市大学的专家合作，对尸体进行尸检。八米长的布氏鲸和组织样本的进一步分析正在进行中。

;

;这头鲸于7月13日首次在西贡海域被发现游泳和进食，引起了居民的极大兴趣，许多人前往西贡海域。

;

;但是上周一发现了一具鲸鱼尸体，据信是同一种哺乳动物，其背鳍附近有一个新伤口，部分器官和肌肉组织突出。早些时候发现它的背部有两处伤口，怀疑是由螺旋桨造成的。

;

;尸体被从海里打捞出来，并运到万宜水库西坝的一个地点。

;

;香港水域发现鲸鱼尸体引发游客愤怒

;

;卫生署表示，经咨询专家并评估处理鲸鱼尸体的方案后，决定将鲸鱼埋葬在大坝附近的地点。

;

;发言人表示：“将采取适当程序，确保整个过程符合卫生、消毒要求以及环境保护原则。”

;

;自然腐烂后，该部门补充说，尸体将被送往海洋公园进行研究。

;

;该部门的工作人员将于周一进入该地区进一步调查并开始埋葬程序，在此过程中将使用机器和化学品。

;

; >;

;它表示希望鲸鱼骨架最终能够变成标本，用于教育和保护目的。

;

;同时，它敦促公众不要接近该地点。

;

;在鲸鱼目击引发的一系列观鲸活动引发批评后，专家敦促当局加强巡逻并设立禁区，以保护该市水域中发现的数千种物种。

;

;海洋生物学家香港海豚保育会主席张启泰表示，鲸鱼的分解可能需要数月时间，具体取决于温度、天气和土壤条件。

;

;香港将在被游客追捕的鲸鱼死亡

;

;他指出，现场埋葬可以消除运输问题，这是国外的一种做法。

;

;张说，找回完好无损的机会很大。用作标本的骨架。他说，标本可能需要大约两年的时间才能展示。

;唐纳德·特朗普周日表示，他将向美国法院请愿，要求法官在他的法庭上担任法官。刑事审判回避，认为负责决定前总统命运的陪审团的人不会给他一个公平的摇篮。

;

;这位两度弹劾的共和党人和前美国总统对起诉他的人发起了一系列谩骂。或负责审理他因试图推翻 2020 年选举结果并欺骗美国而面临指控的案件。

;

;他的最新目标：美国地方法院法官塔尼娅·查特坎 (Tanya Chutkan)，他是民主党前总统巴拉克·奥巴马 (Barack Obama) 任命的主审法官

;

;“当法官‘指派’处理荒谬的言论自由/公平选举案件时，我不可能得到公正的审判。每个人都知道这一点，她也知道，”特朗普在他的真相社交平台上用全部大写字母发布。

;

;“我们将立即以非常有力的理由要求这位法官回避，同样地，华盛顿是一个黑人占多数的城市，严重倾向于民主党。楚特坎拒绝了特朗普法律团队最近的要求。周六，她否认了延长选举期限的动议。回应美国政府保护令请求的最后期限可能会限制特朗普及其律师公开分享有关其案件的内容。

;

;特朗普团队希望将最后期限推迟到周四，但法官表示他们必须遵守目前的截止日期是周一下午 5 点。

;

;Chutkan，61 岁，是华盛顿联邦地区法院的十几名法官之一，被随机分配负责此案。

;

;她有一个她与特朗普有着悠久的法律历史，她在 2021 年 11 月的一起案件中做出了对特朗普不利的裁决，其中特别宣称“总统不是国王”，并对当年 1 月 6 日袭击美国国会大厦的特朗普支持者判处了长期徒刑。;

;检察官要求法官在特朗普“报复”帖子后发布保护令

;

;作为 2024 年共和党总统提名竞选的领跑者，特朗普不仅反击了她，还还诋毁华盛顿。

;

;周四受审后不久，他对针对他的四项指控表示无罪，并向记者发表讲话，称首都是“肮脏和腐烂”的城市。

;

; >;

;特朗普在选举案中的审判日期预计将于 8 月 28 日在 Chutkan 举行的听证会上宣布。

;随着澳大利亚和美国努力深化军事联盟，澳大利亚和美国的两项重大任务第33届澳美部长级磋商（AUSMIN）将极大影响亚太地区的和平与稳定平衡。

;

;其一，美国承诺加强其在战略军事领域的轮换部队存在澳大利亚基地，并派遣核动力潜艇更频繁地访问该国。第二，美国同意帮助澳大利亚培养制造导弹的能力。

;

;这些计划引发了媒体关注和公众评论。尽管如此，澳大利亚国防部长理查德·马勒斯仍持乐观态度，希望看到导弹在两年内开始生产。他说：“此时此刻，澳大利亚没有比美国更好的朋友了。”

;

;随着乌克兰旷日持久的战争，生产导弹等武器的能力已成为焦点，因为其影响至关重要。全球军事库存和物资。华盛顿深陷乌克兰危机，同时又专注于威慑中国，对其军事机制暴露的脆弱性感到焦虑 — — 这引发了人们对其维持军事实力和在世界舞台影响力的能力的不确定性。

;<乌克兰冲突凸显了现代战争中无缝、不间断的供应链的至关重要性，特别是对于地对地导弹而言。这场危机的复杂性越来越清楚地表明，运作良好的弹药分配在维持战场上的战术优势和战略效力方面不可或缺的作用。

;

;美国的目标似乎是通过合作来增强其军事能力。选择其亚太盟友加入其国防工业生产链 — — 表面上是为了解决乌克兰的弹药短缺问题，但更重要的是，向北京表明其计划在需要时发动一场长期战争以支持台湾。

;

;最近举行的AUSMIN论坛毫无疑问地表明，澳大利亚已成为华盛顿在亚太地区对抗中国影响力的首选合作伙伴。马勒斯的“没有更好的朋友”的夸耀证实了这一点。

;

;这些事态发展揭示了美国为巩固军事实力和地区影响力而进行的战略机动，利用联盟向中国展示实力，从而塑造了一种自信的叙事。威慑和地缘政治主导地位。

;

;随着地缘政治动态的不断发展，美国和澳大利亚之间的关系通过澳大利亚海军司令部（AUSMIN）取得了令人感兴趣的飞跃，为两国关系翻开了新的篇章，同时也给美国和澳大利亚的关系提出了新的挑战。具有讽刺意味的是，尽管澳大利亚几十年来没有遇到真正的外部威胁，但它却卷入了几乎所有美国发起的海外战争。这引发了人们对其一贯支持美国冒险主义的担忧。

;

;通过充当华盛顿对华侵略立场的前线基地，澳大利亚似乎将自己束缚在一条不稳定的道路上，并将点燃的导火索交到了美国的手中。美国决策者继续对中国采取挑衅性态度。

;

;这种纠缠引发了人们对澳大利亚战略选择以及进一步卷入美国精心策划的动荡地缘政治的潜在后果的质疑。澳大利亚在这场大国博弈中的角色最终可能会使其在复杂的全球事务舞台上面临不可预测的不利结果。

;

;早在 2021 年，澳大利亚就在随着奥库斯协议的签署，人们对其作为美国利益坚定支持者的发展轨迹表示担忧。

;

;最近在布里斯班举行的澳大利亚军事部长论坛进一步巩固了澳大利亚与美国的军事合作。特别是，通过接受美国帮助生产制导武器，澳大利亚表明了对美国军工联合体的更大承诺。

;

;澳大利亚国防军司令部公布了一系列雄心勃勃的防务合作蓝图，旨在强化澳大利亚作为全球军事大国的作用。美国的战略军事伙伴帮助堪培拉在亚太地区发挥影响力。但日益加深的纠缠也可能进一步将澳大利亚束缚于美国的突发奇想和地缘政治野心，有可能使澳大利亚陷入并非其自身的冲突，并损害其外交政策的自主权。

;

;澳大利亚必须决定：中国是否是一个大国？朋友还是敌人？

;

;堪培拉似乎在不知不觉中陷入了将美国利益置于自身利益之上的战略泥潭，为与中国的潜在冲突铺平了道路。

;

;升级版人们普遍认为，美澳军事合作是为了对抗中国在亚太地区的影响力而共同努力的。美国国务卿布林肯在澳大利亚海军部长会议后表示，美国和澳大利亚“反对中国破坏南海和东海的航行和飞越自由”，也暴露了反对中国在该地区军事行动的意图。 – 以及对中国的关注度不断加强。

;

;最终，华盛顿对澳大利亚导弹生产能力的促进表明了一个更深刻的动机——将澳大利亚定位为针对中国大陆潜在攻击的桥头堡。如果堪培拉真正寻求和平、繁荣和地区稳定，就必须重新评估其对华盛顿印太战略的承诺。

;

;与美国过于密切结盟会带来需要更仔细考虑的后果 — — 如果澳大利亚希望维护自己的利益的话它的利益和自主权。

;教皇方济各周日告诉年轻人，天主教会需要他们，并敦促他们追随他们的梦想，他以大型露天弥撒结束了在葡萄牙举行的世界青年日，并宣布下一届青年日将在三十年来首次在亚洲举行。

;

;有消息称，首尔、韩国将于 2027 年主办世界青年日，这反映出该大陆对天主教会的重要性日益增加，因为天主教会在那里年轻且正在成长，而在欧洲传统的基督教土地上，天主教会正在衰落。

;

;弗朗西斯弥撒结束时，估计有 150 万朝圣者在场，其中许多人在里斯本球场露营过夜，以便能够就位观看天主教节日的压轴戏。梵蒂冈表示，加入他们的还有大约 700 名主教和 10,000 名神父。

;

;方济各周日基本上遵循剧本，但再次跳过了大部分准备好的讲道，继续了他五天葡萄牙之旅的即兴创作。主持里斯本版的世界青年日。

;

;150万勇敢的人群热衷于在葡萄牙见到教皇方济各

;

;在他担任教皇十年的早期，方济各经常前往流氓并无视他预先计划的演讲，似乎被这一刻所感动，甚至直接与一大群人接触。近年来，他在很大程度上坚持剧本，尤其是在访问基督徒占少数的地方或观众可能不欣赏他的非正式风格的地方时。

;

;但在里斯本，他又回到了舒适的地盘，许多人可以轻松地听懂他的母语西班牙语，并且似乎很欣赏他的对话方式。他们似乎也很欣赏大规模的参加人数。

;

;“我从未想过会有这么多人来”，里斯本 23 岁的西班牙朝圣者安娜·加西亚·普拉特 (Ana Garcia Prat) 说道。 “在我的脑海里，我从未想象过有这么多来自不同国家的人参加弥撒。”周日，教宗方济各敦促年轻人追随他们的梦想，不要害怕失败，重申了一个主题圣约翰·保罗二世在其四分之一个世纪的世界青年日期间经常重复这一点。

;

;“作为年轻人，你们想要改变世界，你们想要改变世界并为正义和正义而努力，这是件好事。和平”，弗朗西斯说。 “教会和世界需要你们，年轻人，就像大地需要雨水一样”。

;

;“不要害怕！”

;

;方济各特别赞扬约翰·保罗，回顾他在 20 世纪 80 年代发起的世界青年日活动，以激励下一代天主教徒。约翰·保罗 (John Paul) 于 1995 年在菲律宾马尼拉主持了有史以来规模最大的青年节聚会之一，这是该节日最后一次在亚洲举办。

;

;方济各宣布首尔将主办 2027 年青年节后举着巨大国旗的韩国青少年欢呼雀跃地跳上舞台。半个世纪前，天主教徒约占韩国人口的 1%；现在，天主教徒约占韩国人口的 1%。如今，他们占 5000 万人口的 10%，梵蒂冈的统计数据显示，每年有超过 10 万人受洗。

;

;通常，信仰节日在八月举行，这是韩国最热的月份。即使是今年，也有人因气温过高而呼吁缩短大型国际童军节。

;

;值得注意的是，弗朗西斯没有承诺会在首尔 - 2027 年他将年满 90 岁。但他指出，那里2025 年，梵蒂冈将举办青年盛会，预计将吸引超过 3000 万朝圣者前往罗马。

;

;在过去的几天里，方济各放弃了演讲，转而举行庆祝活动。 - 与年轻人进行即兴交谈，并取代了在法蒂玛神殿为乌克兰和平进行的正式祈祷，长期以来，法蒂玛神殿与俄罗斯的和平与皈依的劝告联系在一起。梵蒂冈后来在社交媒体平台 X（以前称为 Twitter）上发布了部分祈祷文。

;

;在回答有关教皇的健康状况是否是其演讲被忽视的原因的问题时，梵蒂冈发言人马泰奥·布鲁尼 (Matteo Bruni) 表示：说弗朗西斯身体状况良好，没有任何视力问题，这可能会导致阅读他的言论变得困难。

;

;年轻人似乎对他所说的一切感到兴奋。周六，他们冒着 38 摄氏度的酷热，来到现场参加他的晚间守夜仪式。

;

;周日，当太阳从塔霍河上升起时，他们就醒了。许多人睡在垫子、婴儿床和裸露的地面上，准备参加方济各的弥撒，弥撒定于早些时候举行，以避免中午气温预计达到 40 摄氏度。 Starting at dawn, a priest-DJ started spinning thumping reggae and Christian hymns from the sound system.

;

;Francis' message this week has been one of inclusivity, insisting that “everyone, everyone, everyone” has a place in the church. That is consistent with his message that the church isn't a place of rigid rules where only the perfect can be let in, but rather a “field hospital” for wounded souls, where all are welcome.

;

;Lisbon Cardinal Manuel Clemente said the pope wanted the event to be “open … to everyone, showing the breadth of the Gospel, which excludes no one and is open to all.”

;

;“It's something really important in today's world to accept us as we are, and to know our place as Christians, and to validate it”, said Doriane Kilundu, a 23-year-old pilgrim from the Democratic Republic of Congo. “We really support the message of the pope and we are happy to be here”.

;

;Kilundu said the experience of spending the night on the field, with 1.5 million other people of faith, was a first for her and other Congolese pilgrims.

;

;“I'm in the company of young girls from my country that for the first time are confronted with people from other places, and to understand that we are one nation, and for us is beautiful,” she said.

; Sun, 06 Aug 2023 21:20:02 +0800 Hong Kong jobseekers on dependent visas hampered by language skills as employers ‘pivot’ to mainland China markethttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/hong-kong-economy/article/3230129/hong-kong-jobseekers-dependent-visas-hampered-language-skills-employers-pivot-mainland-china-market?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.06 21:07;
;;

;Ace Ara came to Hong Kong to start a new life in his wife's hometown in June 2022, but little did he know that the decision was the beginning of a year-long job hunt spanning about 500 applications.

;

;Despite being legally allowed to work in the city, Ara, 28, a British national, is one of many expats in Hong Kong on a dependent visa who has struggled to find work because of a growing requirement for Cantonese- and Mandarin-speaking skills.

;

;Experts have warned that employers are sceptical about hiring people on dependent visas and if Hong Kong wants to remain an international city, the job market must accommodate them.

;

;Hong Kong school hunt 'miserable' for some mainland arrivals on talent pass

;

;A consultant at a semi-official Beijing think tank also said the government, commercial sector and other industries should work out a comprehensive approach to attract talent, including offering help to dependent visa holders.

;

;Immigration Department data shows that from 2018 to 2022, authorities approved about 23,500 dependent visas per year.

;

;From January this year to June, the number of approvals of dependent visas skyrocketed to 48,691, largely because of the Top Talent Pass Scheme.

;

;Introduced last December, the scheme allows people with an annual income of HK$2.5 million (US$320,000) or more and graduates from the world's top 100 universities to apply for residency in Hong Kong.

;

;More than 95 per cent of the approved applicants were mainland Chinese and the scheme was directly responsible for 22,751 of the dependent visas issued from January to June.

;

;The remaining 25,940 were the partners and children of expats and mainlanders with work or study visas, people married to Hongkongers, as well as their children and parents.

;

;Hong Kong talent drive attracts over 100,000 applications, 61 per cent approved

;

;In June last year, Ara married a Hongkonger and moved to the city. By August, he had successfully applied for a dependent visa and a Hong Kong identity card, granting him the legal right to work in the city.

;

;“I was applying for IT support and web development roles, because that is my field,” he said. “I went for jobs with English postings that did not state a need for Cantonese.

;

;“I prioritised international companies with international staff but the first question in nearly every interview was, 'Do you speak Chinese?'”

;

;Ara, who had five years of experience in IT support and web development and studied the latter at Staffordshire University, said more than 90 per cent of employers he had applied to rejected him because he did not speak Cantonese.

;

;“The constant rejection started to have a huge effect on our lives.我们都靠我妻子的工资生活，所有的账单都是她付的，”阿拉说。 “It was a real struggle.”

;

;Ara spent most of his time applying for jobs, updating his web development portfolio and studying Cantonese to improve his employability.

;

;“I studied Cantonese for two hours in the morning and two hours at night. I even found a language exchange partner online.”

;

;Why are mainland Chinese professionals dominating Hong Kong's talent hunt?

;

;As his desperation grew, Ara aired his troubles in a Facebook group for expats in Hong Kong in May 2023.

;

;Since then, 20 people in Hong Kong on dependent visas have contacted Ara or posted similar stories in the group.

;

;An agency helping expats find work in Hong Kong saw Ara's Facebook post and subsequently helped him secure a six-month contract working in IT for the British Council, a move he hoped would become permanent.

;

;Ara admitted that the situation was so bleak before he found work that the couple had discussed leaving Hong Kong.

;

;One of those who also posted in the Facebook group was Belgian digital journey manager Phillipe Mertens*, who works for a major local bank in his country, and married his Hongkonger wife in 2021.

;

;Mertens, 28, said he had four years of work experience in his field, a master's degree in international commerce from Queen's University in Canada and that he had applied for more than 100 jobs over the past year.

;

;He admitted that being based abroad was a hindrance but he was willing to fund his relocation and future visa fees.

;

;“I have an address in Hong Kong, a Hong Kong phone number and do online interviews at 3 or 4am.”

;

;Mertens said he had been applying for roles in international companies in banking, finance, insurance, aviation and energy.

;

;He and his wife agreed they would try hunting in Hong Kong but if he did not find a job within a year, he would return to Belgium.

;

;Hong Kong rejoins world's top 5 places with highest expat pay and benefits

;

;Sid Sibal, vice-president of Greater China at recruitment firm Hudson, said it was becoming more difficult for dependent visa holders to get work in Hong Kong.

;

;“Firstly, more Chinese firms are establishing a presence in Hong Kong and Western firms have slowed down hiring,” he said.

;

;“This means Hong Kong firms do more business with Chinese ones and the need for English declines.

;

;“Also, businesses are pivoting towards the China market here so as a result if you do not speak either Cantonese or Mandarin, you are at a disadvantage.”

;

;Alexa Chow Yee-ping, managing director of executive search agency ACTS Consulting, agreed that Hong Kong's job market had focused more on Chinese speakers in recent years.

;

;“Over the last 10 to 15 years there has been an increasing emphasis on finding Mandarin- and Cantonese-speaking workers,” she said.

;

;Is Hong Kong worth the cost for expats? Workers weigh chance to live the good life

;

;Chow also put this down to the growth of the mainland's economy and increasing cooperation with Hong Kong.

;

;She said some employers were sceptical about hiring people on a dependent visa.

;

;“They are concerned because the visa depends on their partner, so if [the partners] leave Hong Kong, lose their job or get divorced, the dependents will also lose their visa,” she said.

;

;However, Chow noted that while the city was seeking to attract more overseas talent and retain workers, partners struggling to find work could be a deterrent.

;

;“This is a dilemma. For Hong Kong to maintain its status as an international city, it should appeal to overseas talent [and their families],” she said.

;

;Professor Lau Siu-kai, a consultant at semi-official think tank the Chinese Association of Hong Kong and Macau Studies, said the government should formulate a comprehensive plan to attract and retain overseas talent, and commission NGOs to help dependents find jobs.

;

;He noted that local universities sometimes helped the spouses of overseas professors to find a job in the city.

;

;“Commercial and other sectors should also be involved to foster a comprehensive or holistic approach.”

;

;Lau said he believed that in an international city such as Hong Kong not all companies required jobseekers from overseas to speak Chinese.

;

;“I do not think all jobs in Hong Kong require you to speak English, Cantonese and Mandarin. For example, for the technology industry, it is not a must to be proficient in Chinese.”

;

;* Name changed at request of interviewee

;Less than two weeks after a military coup in the West African country of Niger, China is unlikely to do much beyond supporting existing mechanisms to solve security threats in the Sahel, a vast region that Beijing has substantial interests in, according to observers.

;

;After the July 26 coup, Niger became the latest country in the unstable region to join a list of other nations now under military rule – including Mali, Burkina Faso, Chad and Sudan.

;

;The Sahel, a semiarid region south of the Sahara desert, stretches like a belt from the Atlantic coast of Senegal through parts of Mauritania, Mali, Burkina Faso, Niger, Nigeria, Chad and Sudan. The transitional zone between the arid Sahara to the humid savannahs to the south has been plagued by political instability and widespread jihadist insurgency.

;

;What the Niger coup means for China's presence in the Sahel

;

;China, which maintains an official policy of not meddling in the internal affairs of other nations, could opt to bankroll regional security forces, the African Union or UN-led initiatives to cure instability in the Sahel region, according to observers.

;

;“I hope the personal safety of President [Mohamed] Bazoum, a friend of China, could be assured,” Wu Peng, China's director general of the Department of African Affairs of the Foreign Ministry, said on the social media platform X, formerly known as Twitter, on Wednesday.

;

;Wu said he had noted the statements by the United Nations and the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), a regional political and economic bloc of 15 countries, that have condemned Bazoum's removal .

;

;ECOWAS has given the junta until Sunday to reinstate the democratically elected president.

;

;China hopes the parties concerned will act in the fundamental interest of the country and its people, and resolve disputes peacefully through dialogue to see order restored and stability and development safeguarded, Wu said.

;

;“I believe Niger and regional countries have the wisdom and capacity to seek a political resolution,” he added.

;

;In the coming weeks, the UN peacekeeping mission in Mali, where China has hundreds of troops, will start leaving following a UN resolution in June, a decision that came after the ruling military in the capital of Bamako pushed for the removal of the international forces.

;

;France, which had maintained military operations in the Sahel, has been pulling its forces out from most of the Sahelian countries, including Burkina Faso, where operations by the French army were ended in February, following demands by the country's government.

;

;Adding to the region's security challenges, the anti-terrorism G5 Sahel Joint Force – formed in 2017 by Burkina Faso, Chad, Mali, Mauritania and Niger, and bankrolled by the West and China – has largely been unsuccessful.

;

;“This was to happen within the framework of the G5 Sahel, but it could not, because the G5 Sahel had trouble taking off, and when it finally did, there were coups in Mali and then in Burkina Faso that rendered it moot,” said Rahmane Idrissa, a senior researcher at the African Studies Centre at Leiden University in the Netherlands.

;

;To function properly, he said the G5 Sahel needed an effective collective security strategy, reforms in the security sector, and development initiatives.

;

;Idrissa said the junta in Mali and Burkina Faso had rejected the G5 Sahel on the basis of mostly ideological reasons – they saw it as breaching their sovereignty since the French helped set it up, even though it was a genuinely Sahelian initiative, mostly pushed by Mauritania and Niger.

;

;In 2019, China contributed US$45.6 million to the G5 Joint Force's security and counterterrorism operations.

;

;Nevertheless, the void is being filled by the Wagner Group, a Russian mercenary company, which has been accused of massacres in Mali, and elsewhere in the Sahel and central Africa.

;

;Alex Vines, head of the Africa programme at the London-based Chatham House think tank, said that with the drawdown of the UN in Mali, there is concern that West Africa's security should not be subcontracted to private foreign militaries.

;

;“ECOWAS is seeking to establish a regional army to respond to counterterrorism threats and coups,” he said.

;

;Although the intent was for the region to fund such a force, equipment and additional training would be sought from international partners, including China, Vines said.

;

;ECOWAS is also looking for predictable funding, including from UN contributions, something in which China can promote through the UN Security Council, he said.

;

;China has extensive economic interests in the Sahel region, which is rich in minerals such as uranium, gold, iron ore, manganese and oil.

;

;Chinese companies have also invested in Mali's lithium mining and Mauritania's fishing industries. China National Petroleum Company (CNPC) is a major investor in Chad's petroleum industry.

;

;In Niger, Chinese companies have investments in oil and uranium.中石油正在建设一条2,000公里（1,243英里）长的原油管道，从尼日尔东南部油田到邻国贝宁的港口码头。 But work at the pipeline project may have stopped after the Chinese embassy in Niger told Chinese citizens in Niger to “be vigilant” and “avoid going out”.

;

;Zhou Yuyuan, a senior fellow and deputy director at the Centre for West Asian and African Studies at the Shanghai Institutes for International Studies, said China would continue to support peace efforts led by the United Nations, and has pledged to provide financial support and equipment to the African Union and the G5 Sahel Joint Force.

;

;While Beijing had increased its peace and security cooperation with African countries, its security role in Africa was still weak and could be described as supportive or complementary, Zhou said.

;

;“Facing the rising security needs of the Sahel region, I think China may continue to support the United Nations, the African Union and regional security forces to play a major role in solving the security threats, and even possibly support France and the European Union to play active roles,” he said.

;

;David Shinn, a China-Africa expert and professor at George Washington University's Elliott School of International Affairs, said both Washington and Beijing would seek political stability in the Sahel.

;

;But while Washington preferred to work with democratic leaders, Shinn said Beijing was willing to work with either democratic or authoritarian governments to maintain stability.

;

;China likely to take bigger role in peacekeeping missions in West Africa

;

;China has never supported active military engagement in Africa, and that is not likely to change, Shinn said. “China provided several hundred peacekeepers to the UN peacekeeping operation in Mali, but they were involved in defensive operations and, in any event, will soon be leaving with the ending of the UN mission there,” he said, adding that Beijing was unlikely to fill the gap left by France or the US.

;

;“Even if French and American forces are forced out of the area, it is unlikely that China will want to fill the void in this increasingly treacherous environment.”

;

;Benjamin Barton, an associate professor at the University of Nottingham's Malaysia campus, said China's active presence in the security dynamics of the Sahel region would appear to be limited and restricted to a diplomatic role.

;

;“Unlike France, Beijing is unlikely to lead or form part of a spontaneous military coalition to restore stability,” Barton said.

;

;China's main geopolitical interest in the region is the status quo and further curating its image and budding influence, he said.

;

;“I would foresee China possibly playing a diplomatic role here, but given how critical this situation is for the French state, China may want to take a back seat and focus more on matters of direct concern, such as evacuating its nationals and seeking ways of protecting Chinese investments in case the situation escalates,” he said.
